column1: Blepharitis is swelling or inflammation of the eyelids.
In people with blepharitis, too much oil is produced by the glands near the eyelid.
Blepharitis is more likely to be seen in people with: - A skin condition called seborrheic dermatitis or seborrhea.

This problem involves the scalp, eyebrows, eyelids, skin behind the ears, and the creases of the nose - Allergies that affect the eyelashes (less common) - Excess growth of the bacteria that are normally found on the skin - Rosacea, which is a skin condition that causes a red rash on the face Blepharitis may be an underlying cause of repeated styes and chalazia.

Symptoms include: - Red, irritated eyelids - Scales that stick to the base of the eyelashes - Burning feeling in the eyelids - Crusting, itching and swelling of the eyelids You may feel like you have sand or dust in your eye when you blink.
Your health care provider might recommend using baby shampoo or special cleansers.
- After the warm compresses, gently rub a solution of warm water and no-tears baby shampoo along your eyelid, where the lash meets the lid, using a cotton swab.
Continuing treatment will ease redness and help make your eyes more comfortable
